AmYFXhAZNnKy4eYUdqmM6A.text: Wow... RUDE AND WORST SERVICE EVER.. first timer, so I asked for a BBQ recommendation from the menu, waitress gave me a dirty look and told me she will be back when I am ready... I was so shocked by her rude attitude, I lost my appetite.  Paid for the food and left...

rSy-WSmDkKjcv42X8svnFA.text: Busy busy busy,  the reason why is because the food is very good and lots of people come here time and time again.  The price are reasonable but the alcohol drinks can be on the high side.  The staff are friendly and the service is standard and fast. I think they need a bigger place

ET7YA6q64oFO-LJKHfFGSw.text: Such great peking duck here, the best I've had in London so far. Great food in general actually - everything tastes authentic.

ogcfvhm4chA3ZzLzNKXFTw.text: I come here once a week for duck and rice off the bone, and it is superb. Every. Time. Staff are friendly, even if they do bring your orange slices half way through your meal!  All the meats here are tip-top, I'd avoid everything else except the veg. Enjoy!

sdS-Ul6dsAetPI1b7R4CNw.text: great roast duck ever! even better than the one i tried in China. I will recommend this place to frds even always need to wait in long queues for nearly half an hour.

82o2Wew9hGcdft7ZuMyCZQ.text: Went here for a special dinner with my husband and was unfortunately very disappointed. The service was poor and the seating was terrible. I know it is London and they need to make use of every space possible but there is almost no room to move around. The other issue is if you sit downstairs like we did they you get the lovely smell of toilette cleaner and trash coming in to the lower dinning area. As for the food my husband and I agreed almost immediately that we have had WAY better Chinese food at a food court in the mall for a fraction of the price. Overall I strongly recommend you avoid this place. If your looking for really good Chinese food in China town I am sure there are plenty of other options, one that we did really like was WONKEY - Great value, great food, friendly staff.

7Bx4yZQ04NvCh3OAgZUxmA.text: Part of the famous Four Seasons family of restaurants, this branch is less crowded than its sister located on Leicester Square but the food is no less delicious. I have to confess that I haven't tried that many dishes here, but, honestly, if you're at this place, you're here for one thing and one thing only: the roast duck.I've found roast duck in London a whole different ball game compared to the Far East. For some reason, the ducks here are much fatter, so there's more meat to be had, and, a lot more fat attached to the oh-so-tasty skin. I tend to scrape the fat off as there's only so much my arteries can take, but I will admit that it adds a lot of flavour, life-shortening though it may be!The other barbecued meats are good too; I like the roasted pork while my friend prefers the crispy pork. And the gravy? To die for.Oh, and if you like spicy food, ask for a bowl of chilli oil. It's much nicer than the bog standard chilli sauce option. It's not vegetarian as it's served with dried shrimp (which is why it's so tasty) so, if that's a consideration, please bear it in mind!In terms of atmosphere, Four Seasons is no better or worse than any of the other Chinese establishments nearby, although it may have been a little cleaner than the rest.The service here was decent. Our waiter wasn't rude, he spoke English and he was pretty quiet. As I said, decent.

WJGqn6R3ys5k3mVEh8QHEQ.text: Tiny place, squeezed into corner downstairs. tasteless wonton soup, sweet and sour chicken has a slither of chicken ie - just batter. Service was good

E09-lFIvoy3wzqRhifUZqQ.text: Duck...all the way...and the large pea sprouts.....it was worth it. Take away is not bad either!

8zeBO5aHkY57kAyXA5XTVQ.text: We read that this had the best roast duck in town and saw that there were people (including many Chinese people) waiting to eat there so thought it must be good, authentic Chinese food.I have to say the char sui pork is the best I have ever had. And this is why it gets 4 stars.The duck however was just not impressive. The skin was really chewy and not crispy. The meat was nice but because the skin was bad it kinda ruined "the best roast duck in town" for us.We also had a side of noodles and beansprouts which were damn tasty.Less than average service. 12.5% discretionary service charge included on bill.

186EsXzG9MzakJhdK2hAZg.text: I was unsure what to expect from the Chinese food here in London, but I must say I was pleased with my lunch at Four Seasons in Chinatown. First off, this area of London is much nicer and maintained than most Chinatowns I have been to in the US, which is several. It does not however ruin any of the traditional market-type feel I personally look for in a great Chinatown experience.Now to the restaurant, there is something comforting about fresh roasted duck and pig hanging in the front window. The entry way is a bit crammed, which I can see being a bit troublesome at busier times. We went here on a Sunday afternoon around 12:30 hoping for dim sum, but it turned out it was not being served. Not sure if this is normal or not, but it was definitely disappointing. Seating-wise it was slightly confined, so be prepared to sit directly next to people you don't know (basically at the same table). Aside from the close quarters the restaurant did not seem overly crowded.For starters I ordered a bowl of Fish Maw soup, which is my absolute favourite. The flavor was great, no complaints whatsoever, but in my opinion it could have either been a bit thicker or had more meat. I was a bit surprised when they only brought out an individual bowl as the menu listed it at £6, and I assumed that would be for the group. I guess that is just London for you though...We also ordered 1/2 a crispy duck for the three of us to share, which could have been more food for the price. It was served shredded with a stack of warm rice wraps and fresh veggies. In all honesty I thought this tasted excellent and the delivery was great. I liked how they gave us the bones too in case we wanted to shred a bit more off (which we did). The sauce was a bit sweet for my taste, but I tend to prefer more salty/savory sauces with meat.All in all, I will definitely be coming back here to explore more of their menu. I will just have to do more research on when dim sum is served/not served next time before coming.

h72aI3aOAdSyh9XvQp0ouw.text: At the end of our meal here...What I was tempted to say to the help: Ni you mao bing ma?!What I actually said: Wo men ke bu ke yi mai dan?----On the one hand, the food is generally quite respectable. At Uli's suggestion, we came for the duck, and plenty of fowl was had. The whole steamed fish will run you a pretty penny at twenty quid, but was quite fresh, thought not flavourful. The garlic sautéed greens (in our case, Chinese broccoli) were crunchy and tender, a rare and appreciated combination of textures. If you're into salt and pepper pork, their version's not bad.However, as forewarned, the service here was acceptable at best, condescending and irritable at worst. I'm reasonably certain if we were made to feel any more unwelcome, we'd have walked out. It was a razor thin edge. Every single request we made was met with an attitude of disgruntlement, as though it was an extreme burden to bring a clean replacement plate or a takeaway box for leftovers.That's fine. I'm happy to go spend that £60 somewhere else in future.----I'm trying to decide if the three-star review for Four Seasons was as a result of an experiential upgrade due to a rare opportunity to enjoy a rare meal with the ever-lovely Michele D. A teetering four-star sampling of food with solidly two-star service amounts to all-around mediocrity.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom

hecdsvZyO_aw00dMvzpuLQ.text: With so many aromatic crispy duck options in Chinatown it is hard to choose - but glad I settled on Four Seasons. Claiming they are "roast duck specialists" they did luckily not disappoint. Duck was not prepared at the table but was without a doubt truly delicious and reasonably priced. As you expect in Chinatown the service was not particularly welcoming and quite gruff really but all in all highly recommend.

7aMibtklUIx5G_26borf8A.text: Oh dear, it seems like Four Seasons has been reading the Starbucks fast franchising doctrine. Apparently, Starbucks have a way of calculating when one branch is too busy and you need to open another branch even if it is literally round the corner from the other branch.The original Four Seasons in Queensway is a legend, drawing large crowds for its roast duck. The next branch opened on the main drag of Chinatown on Gerrard Street with the word 'Queensway' in brackets on its shop sign to remind everyone of its more illustrious older sibling.However, not more than 47 steps (yes, I counted them!) from the Gerrard Street branch, you'll find yet another branch of Four Seasons.The roast duck is good but I find the accompanying soya suace a bit sweet. They do offer the duck off the bone, which is a service not found much in Chinatown. My current personal favourite for roast duck though is Tai Ka Lok on Gerrard Street.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom

2uJ8zXlRYmYC48Ws2VYLaw.text: Great fatty roasted duck! We had to squeeze at a table with 3 people and they subtly chase you away after you're done.

ULT7OxANrCG0UPZDJWtzLA.text: When I want Cantonese BBQ duck, I want the duck to have 1) juicy flesh, 2) crispy skin and 3) nice duck flavor.  Four Seasons seems to hit one of the three.  I admit the duck is very juicy --more than the ducks you typically find in Asia.  The skin, however, is flabby.  A good BBQ duck should contrast the fatty meat with a nicely rendered, crispy skin.  And what's with the sauce?  It's like pouring sugar water on top of meat to drown out any flavor that the meat might have had.  While I think there is a place for sugar on duck (I personally love dipping Peking duck skin into coarse sugar), I find the sauce here disgusting. Service is also not great here.  There always seems to be a queue, and the staff is pushy to get you out and generate turnover on tables.  The other dishes are standard sub-par Cantonese fare.  The restaurant itself is dirty.  I think I was spoiled growing up in Canada, where you could find excellent Cantonese food anywhere without having to go to a tourist trap.  Skip it.

M0ZqFCvkd-mN26FDj5oG_w.text: There's a newspaper article emblazoned on the door claiming "best roast duck in the world"; bold but it is certainly the best I've had in London.Come here regularly for the roast duck and crispy pork belly - both are excellent and compensate for the fact it's very busy and queues are common. The setting is fairly small so don't expect privacy.Waiting staff are attentive and friendly, although keen to keep the restaurant turning over so don't expect to linger over a coffee and some romantic chat.

0Fz68mPsZpbPQplpri3-cA.text: Wow...wow...wow!!!I loved the barbecue meats that they are so famous for here! All the previous reviewers are right: try the roasted duck, it's amazingly moist and succulently sweet! In fact, I recommend that if you're here by yourself (for lunch), you order the meal that features three kinds of BBQed meats, served over rice: roasted duck, roasted pork & roasted pork belly. Since it was all so nice and juicy, the rice got flavoured by the meats and it tasted just amazing!Granted, the service is typically Chinese: they want to you to order asap, eat and leave asap so that they can serve the next waiting customers. In other words, don't come here if you want to hang out with your friends and discuss philosophy! But, if you want to enjoy some fabulous and authentic Chinese dinner, then this is the place to come!Food-wise I would give it almost 5 stars, but the rather oblivious service and the rather unwelcoming toilets dampened the overall experience down to 4 stars...

bE3Ux26RFtHbto3Xh7DNWg.text: There are a lot of positives about this place, largely covered in other reviews.  The duck is superb, the rest of the food is pretty good.  The lemon chicken did make me do a Renée Zellweger though.The experience feels a little like dining in a strangers front room, rather chaotic and not especially friendly service.  Very reasonably priced.

Oci5TgWgX5VbfBs-jorB7g.text: They have the best Duck on rice , and make sure u ask for som ginger sauce it makes the dish  the bomb !!

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Roast duck on rice

vcBtfJAwVVrVia04m9fQCA.text: AMAZING!! Wonton soup was superb, chicken fried noodles were delicious and the BBQ pork was insane! This place is the real deal!

GQn8M1KZKTdBa_8M8Yy6eA.text: Love the roast duck!!!  So much so, I had to come here two nights in a row during my stay in London.  The best I have ever had!  I grew up near San Francisco, live in New York now, have been to Hong Kong and China and STILL have not had roast duck like this.  It must be because the duck is ordered from Ireland or something?  The roast duck is so JUICY, TENDER, SUCCULENT, FLAVORFUL and PLUMP.  Did I also mention that it is cheap?  It comes de-boned if you prefer and comes with a side of sweet delicious soy sauce.  I do wish the skin was a bit crispier, but the flavor is just overwhelmingly good that I'd still give it 5 stars.Service is great!  I am used to rude service at Chinese restuarants but this place is not like that at all.  They actually hand you menus for every person in your party, do not throw your food down or rush you out the door!  It was amazing! There is always a wait, but it goes by quite fast.  Stand your ground and do not be tempted to go to the other subpar restaurants in the area.  There is a reason why there is a wait, and this place is totally worth it!

obQs9Ia2_32vp2nmlD51-A.text: Great Chinese duck,  both Pechinese style as starter (cold,  to be eaten with pancakes) and fantastic in Cantonese style (fat and juicy). If you want Chinese duck at very good value,   this is your place. Service is a bit rough, though. I really recommend, I came back here many times,  never disappointed. Wine list has also some very cheap option, for London.

w0x5UmsrHjdZ2tiVAK--EA.text: Heard many people mentioned this restaurant, so I finally went there for dinner. This is a Cantonese restaurant and the daily soup is a sure way to test whether this is a good restaurant. Usually the daily soup is some sort of meat cooked for hour with vegetable and even Chinese herb, and often time has medicinal benefits. The daily soup we had was really delicious. Besides the soup, my friend and I also ordered one meat dish and one vegetable, which were tasty. The portions were quite generous, so you won't go hungry here. I heard the Beijing Duck here is a specialty. I have to give it a try next time.

UpgrVehnQXLuOaiQeJFq3A.text: Very disappointing. This place is smack dab in the middle of 20 other Chinese restaurants in London's drab version of Chinatown. Four Seasons was the only one with a line, which we took to mean that it had quality food. Our bill was close to $120 for 2 people with 1 beer each, a bottle of still water, and 3-4 unimpressive courses. I wish we had just ordered the peking duck from the window, which actually looked good and cost less than our meals. London in general is overpriced but this place is an absolute rip-off.

DranP2sVL04izbuBPplRnA.text: This place has the best roast duck in town. It's cheaper than the other places but tastes much better. They are very busy though, and the place isn't big enough. They tend to rush you out as soon as you "finished".

GdNpF1Dh2fp1tNgVGMf_SQ.text: This new branch of Four Seasons absolutely rocks! Everything feels shiny and new, and yet familiar at the same time... I've been here 3-4 times already - it feels much brighter than the other branch in China Town, and there are three floors so I've always managed to get a table.  Of course, the signature roast duck is the same as that in the other branches (which is a very important point to take note of!).  The menu is the same as at other branches.  Overall, just good, homey food - a must if you are looking for a quick, inexpensive meal.

pqhbpPFCigGEYIDQEPK3pA.text: NOT peking duck. We asked for a peking duck and instead of saying "sorry we dont have peking duck" they gave us a roast duck served peking duck style (pancakes, onions, cucumber, hoison sauce and duck skin). Im pretty sure they still call it peking duck.The duck came out room temperature and the skin was soggy and oily. That sounds worse than it was. If I had been expecting a roast duck except for the not hot part it was pretty good. Even though the skin wasnt crispy it was not rubbery and it was easy to eat. The meat itself was good, but shredded. That is probably because it wasnt a peking duck and that was how they got the meat off the skin.We also had the crisp pork belly which came out chilled, I guess that was the intent. It was pretty good we just werent expecting a cold dish.Afterwards we asked them saying we didnt think it was a peking duck, they said the aromatic duck skin was deep fried so that might be a better choice if you want crisp.Cons:Not peking ducksoggy skinlayer of fat still attached to the skin (with peking duck it disappears)roast duck oilycrisp pork belly was coldPros:Tasted goodnot rubbery so easy to eatmeat tasted good.pork belly was good  (would have been better hot).All of this was affordable for two adults, 2 children with leftovers @ 56 pounds. The "peking" duck alone was 35 pounds

n9TUB7Gp1DN-uFWxa3vvAw.text: They should give me a membership card.The roast duck, the claypot lamb, the BBQ pork belly, the pok choy, the spring rolls.. ORGASMIC! The duck is a must every visit. No negotiations! I've tried a lot of the menu and so far I liked everything. I wished I had a bottomless stomach.

7-sug5KhTEYTk9abgwjVNw.text: Each time we come to London, we have a meal at the Four Seasons Chinese Restaurants. There are 3 restaurants, one in Bayswater, one on Waldorf St and the last at 12 Gerrard St, chinatown.We love the Roast Duck Rice meal for £6.80. Ask the  restaurant to debone the Duck and give you extra sauce. The meat is tender and tasty. The restaurant serves other food as well, but this is our favourite dish. The other dishes we like are the stir fried prawn noodle, Kai Lan stir fried with garlic and the stir fried green pea shoots (seasonal).

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom

Bg9TqNsAfklc6RkzllCpIA.text: I have been hearing people raving about the roast duck here for a long time. That has definitely stirred my curiosity and. Finally made a trip down not too long ago. I went in the late afternoon and ordered a portion of roast duck for two. When the roast duck came, I was a tad shock to see how small the portion was. It was a small plate of duck more suited for one. I clarified my order and the server assured me that it's a portion for two. I was disappointed when I realize the meat was little in size and the taste was not as juicy as i had been told. I definitely have had better duck portion and quality elsewhere. It's been a disappointing feed here.

mxb4omPnMUXavgi1Wgz5HA.text: Four seasons is in the middle of London's Chinatown. I stopped in an hour before closing to get a bite to eat. I ordered bean curd, mushrooms with Chinese vegetables, pork chops, and trio meat ( roasted duck, roasted pork, and soy chicken). All the food tasted good, but the portions were on the smaller side. I don't know if it was because they were closing soon, but the bean curd and pork chops were awfully small. However, the food tasted authentic and was tasty. Overall if not for the small portions I would have rated this higher.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Bean curd
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Mushrooms with Chinese vegetables
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Trio meat( roasted duck, soy chicken, and roasted pork.

5KKa8OTYc-GV60byxFA1QQ.text: The roast duck was just ok. We also had the roast pork which was very disappointing. The skin was not crispy and the meat was dry and not juicy at all. Also had the wonton noodle soup and was also disappointed. Overcooked noodles and wontons not up to the satndard we are used to in San Francisco.

FRlc51dKilgxbjibARBi6Q.text: We had a good meal at Four Seasons. I'd had the duck at their Bayswater location but wanted to try this one and see what the other options were like. Crab with spring onion and ginger was good.  Crab was not overcooked and came nicely pre-cracked. The pork belly with preserved veg was melt in your mouth tender and the sauce went well with the rice. Scallops with cellophane noodles were ok. The scallops were not as flavoursome as they could have been. Stir fried greens and braised tofu hit to spot The rice had obviously been sitting around for a while and was not steaming hot and fluffy.  They left the door to the restaurant open which meant the restaurant was cold and our food went cold quite quickly. It was a good meal but nothing too special. Good value though. We all had a beer plus food and it came to £30/pp.

BoWMAMXq2VgjiCGcZ-6joA.text: I went to this place after siting a fellow Food Spotter's picture on FoodSpotting.  Then I cross checked with Yelp, and it was almost 5 stars so I decided to put it on one of to go list when in London.OH BOY am I glad I did go to this place!  This little hole-in-the-wall is known for their roast duck and it is totally worth your trip!  We ordred Roast Duck, Lobster (in spicy and sweet sauce) which's not on the menu, but you ask to be cooked this way they'll do it, Salt & Pepper short ribs, Salty fish & chicken fried rice, and Fried oyster.  Every single dish was absolutely fantastic!  I'm from San Francisco, and if you've heard of R&G Lounge in SF, you know how good they are.  This place is just as good as R&G and even better at some level!  1. Roast Duck: They are famous for this and they sure do it well!  Crispy skin with tender juicy meat and absolutely perfect seasoning!! YUM!2. Sweet & Spicy Lobster: OMG! This lobster is OUT of THIS World delicious!!! When asked if the lobster was fresh, the chap taking our order very confidently said yes! So we asked to make it with some kind of spicy sauce (not on the menu) and they whipped up this lobster. It may not look pretty to you, but it's all pretty when you put it in your mouth! Flavor explosion! BAM! So good and the succulent lobster meat was just so sweet!3.  Salt & Pepper short ribs: Jiao Yen Pai Ku: Perfectly fried! Tender meat! Enuf said!4. Salty fish & Chicken fried rice: So yummy with lots of salty fish in it, not like some places where they skimp on it.5.  Fried oyster: They really know how to fry stuff here and this dish was so good!Place is small, but there are downstairs seatings as well.  People are friendly and if you speak Mandarin or Cantonese it's a plus cuz they'll take care of you really well.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Roast Duck
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Fried Oysters
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Sweet & Spicy Lobster

NOXc-ARcf4CkICuyRx4Log.text: I came to Chinatown expecting a cheap Chinese dinner, we ordered a duck, rice, and half a chicken with two hot and sour soups.  The total came out to be..... $60USD.  I mean don't get me wrong, this place was decent, but I don't know if it's worth $60.  If you REALLY want to get your Chinese craving out of the way, I would recommend this place.  Otherwise, stick to typical london/british food.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Roast duck

Pr6LKKqF2e5Cek5Y5CjW2g.text: One of many decent places to eat in London's surprisingly small Chinatown. I love how ethnic Chinese businesses exude a certain frenetic efficiency while foregoing mainstream courtesies and this place does not disappoint in that regard. Claustrophobics beware: They sit you wherever there is space. On the crowded lunchtime I visited, when I walked in they hurriedly motioned for me to get in and go downstairs (who knew there was a downstairs?) where there is a small room jam packed with tables and people eating elbow to elbow. They sat me at my own small table that was between 2 others with about 3 inches of space between them so I was essentially eating a communal table with 4 other people. This is a little socially uncomfortable since you are so close to the strangers that you can't help but make eye contact at inopportune moments. This makes for an interesting lunch because you can see what they are eating, watch them pick their teeth, listen to them burp, and wonder how in the hell you are going to safely get out of the place when you are finished without a crowbar. The food was good, not great. To be fair, they seem to be known for their hanging roasted BBQ meats but I ordered some dumplings and a bowl of braised beef noodle soup. It was tasty but I've had better and the portions were a little small for the prices in my opinion. But, it hit the spot, was comforting, made me feel like I was sitting right in the middle of the motherland all for £12.90 which was pricey just for the food but reasonable for the forced people-watching entertainment factor that was included. I would probably go back to try something else off the menu but there are so many other places nearby that also deserve my future attention.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Braised beef noodle soup and Pan-fried pork dumplings, 12.90

jsqYy4N4lem26LKsQBYaFg.text: If I'm honest, I think the one on Gerrard Street is better, although that's not to say this isn't a very good Chinese restaurant. This is just off of the main strip of Chinatown, at one end towards the W hotel.The meats are what I go here for, the crispy belly pork, barbecued Char Siu and juicy Roast Duck. The Four Seasons group has a reputation for their staple meats and it is deserved.I go to this branch for takeout as it's closer to work (albeit not by much) and it is generally less busy than the Gerrard Street branch. You're getting the same meats and rice and in that respect it makes no difference. Some dishes I think are better in the other branch when eating in though.In the evening, this branch is a little quieter than the Gerrard Street branch and won't have the staff hassling you to return the table for the next group of people. As much as I compare it to the other branch, it's not different enough to warrant the queues of people waiting for a table at the other location. I would suggest that instead of waiting 40 mins plus, head here instead.

alMNlx6IYiCJ0tNrDCH2Sg.text: Take-away review only!This is a review on the the roast duck! When I past through China Town I always stop by the Four Seasons to but a whole roast deboned duck! In the window there is a sign stating it serves the best roast duck in London - this may well be true! I have yet to taste a better duck. Juicy and succulent everytime! You can buy roast duck for a lot cheaper at nearby restaurants in china town but often I find the duck too fatty or too gamey. I never eat in at Four Seasons so I can't comment on the rest of the menu but the duck is excellent. A perfect night in: a whole roast duck, lots of choi of choice and a movie. Juicy, juicy, juicy!

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Roast duck

s5rcMKvCGotHXZl1hc7ZPg.text: I'd like to rate Four Seasons somewhere between a 3 and 4. I went to their Gerrard Street branch for the first time at a friend's suggestion that they had the best roast duck in Chinatown after my mother insisted I bring a whole duck home for dinner (Chinese parents are weird.) It's fairly clear that Four Seasons know their duck. It wasn't covered it in an entire bag of five spice and they seemed to understood the importance of choosing a duck that isn't covered in half an inch of fat. The accompanying sauce was a delicate balance of sweet and savoury. It was based on this first takeaway experience that I returned a short time later to their Wardour Street branch for a dinner with my mum. The plan had been to order one dish of 3 meats (pork belly, duck and chicken) and supplement it with a stir fried green vegetable but in the end we ordered the meats with a tofu dish instead. The meats were delicious and I was glad to see that they were laid on top of a bed of Chinese leaf so there's no need to feel guilty if you don't order veggies. :P the pork belly was crunchy, duck was excellent and the chicken came with an accompaniment of ginger and coriander dipping sauce, Hainan style. All of it tasted great. Even the rice was fragrant and of a higher standard to what I've become used to in Chinatown. The tofu dish wasn't as pleasant as the rest of our meal.I can't recall the name of it but it was a deep fried tofu with a seafood meatball filling, stirfried in a sauce with a few pak choi. It wasn't awful but the sauce was heavy on MSG and cornflour which gave it a gooey texture and unpleasant aftertaste. Not bad but not the best thing to have when the other half of our meal consisted entirely of meat. It was a hot day so something lighter would have been a better idea. Our choice of dish isn't  the restaurant's fault of course but I still wouldn't order it again. Altogether for 2 people (rice, tea, a meat dish and a vegetable dish) the meal came to £29 including service charge. Of course we got a duck to go after we were done because apparently that's what Chinese mothers need to do. (So weird...) Not bad for the area but for a real bargain order rice & meat individual meal, which comes to about £18 for two + drinks.

wTtmeKvZ4Uy5yuZAXQxSzQ.text: It's always busy at this place, always a queue waiting outside. I gave it a try eventually with a some friends. It was the first for all of us. We didn't have to wait for long to be seated, we went to the second floor, and which was crowded (bit noisy), there was no space between tables. We ordered a few dishes and the soup of the day. The menu stated the soup had no MSG, but we found it quite salty (apparently no MSG but loads of salt). We had some bean curd dish in a pot which was okay, the wok fried Chinese kale with garlic was good, as well as the salt and pepper pork chop. The service deserved a 2 star, it was between minimal and rude (typical).

mEWcfFJ7pa1uQMgMRmuvdA.text: The food was not as pictures in the menu, and the waitresses upstairs are RUDE! The reason why I said that is because I asked for water no ice. We are done with our meal and still no water! instead, they talk chinese loudly close to our table as if they were talking about us, bery rude type, they chit-chatter that they forgot the customer. Don't go here, tidy, food was not even to my great, the Yang-chow fried rice we ordered was not eve close to the picture, the shrimp in it has fishy taste as if it wasn't washed/rinsed well. find some other chinese line up. Go

7p_CrqQZdZf92Guytzpm6w.text: Best dish is roast duck! Black bean beef hor fun has flavorful gravy, though hor fun tad too thick and al dente firm.

WAnRoLkHMk3SNhBxHvCTNg.text: Four Seasons is probably my favorite restaurant in Chinatown. Just a warning: the decor is nonexistent and the service isn't perfect. (What do you expect from an authentic Cantonese restaurant?)But I don't come here for the decor and service... As long as they keep serving their roast duck, I'm happy!Along with the duck, I would recommend the salt and pepper prawns. They're battered, deep fried, and heavily seasoned... Yum.

Eb3hm3bMPyCU10eVetiJOg.text: This was Sunday night and had to wait at least 10-15 mins before we got seated. I've been recommended this business chain by several people to try their duck and boy was I not disappointed (which probably bumped it up to 4 stars).For the price and quality it was great.Would come back for sure.

photos.caption: Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Get the portion, just right amount I feel. But wouldn't say no to extra pieces of duck.
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Tea which is only 1
Photo of Four Seasons - London, United Kingdom. Awesome duck

1mAizCIF0Nz_dHWNkCqGJQ.text: The dish was okay but the service was awful. The waitress tried to kick us out when we were in half way to finish. She came back to our table every other minute and take away everything that she "think" we don't need. If you want to eat something good and be joyful go somewhere else!!!

puD_yMc_K90r7FVHekRhGQ.text: First of all the workers here are unbelievably rude. I politely ask for a table for 3 and they say "okay you all go outside" in a rude voice while shoving his finger at my face to go outside. Fine we waited outside. 10 minutes later 3 groups came into the restaurant and they automatically got seats (I'm sure they didn't have reservations). I ask the guy about our table. His reply was "(unintelligible voice) wait". The food tastes okay compared to the other restaurants in chinatown. They serve very sloppily. Barbecued mixed meat is drowned with sauce. I recommend you try elsewhere in chinatown.

iCYXN82zZuG88NK6oK2DaQ.text: Peking duck here is very good. Easily fed 6 people as a starter and the other dishes were not bad. Spicy here means SPICY.The atmosphere and decor are actually quite poor, and there was a draft from a window that couldn't be closed on the second floor. But if your interest is the food, then you'll not be disappointed.The crispy roast squid and Shredded chicken fried noodles are extremely morish!

nn1IifuIOR-KUNRjo4jVrA.text: I have eaten in plenty of Chinese restaurants in China Town but I have yet to find one that can rival Four Season's famous BBQ meat. The seasoning and texture of its BBQ pork and roast duck are simply outstanding as far as the London standard goes. A typical meal at Four Seasons would cost less than 20 pounds per person to make this one of the best place for comforting but quality Cantonese food in China Town.
